subject: Art
title: Contrast & Attention
description: The area of highest contrast wins the viewer's attention first.

hook.text: Your eye goes to the area of highest contrast. Always. This is hardwired into human vision â€” it's how we evolved to spot threats and opportunities. Use it as your compositional spotlight.

buildup.text: Contrast types: value (light vs dark), color (saturated vs muted, warm vs cool), size (large vs small), detail (complex vs simple), edge (sharp vs soft). All pull the eye, but value contrast is the strongest.

discovery.text: The strategy: place your highest contrast at the focal point. Reduce contrast everywhere else. This creates a natural spotlight effect that guides the eye without any visible tricks.

twist.text: Secondary focal points need medium contrast. Backgrounds need low contrast. It's a gradient of visual energy from the center of interest outward â€” a controlled fade that keeps the eye returning to the star.

climax.text: Rembrandt's technique: bright face against dark background, surrounded by mid-tones. The value contrast at the face is so strong that the eye can't look anywhere else. Pure contrast-driven composition.

punchline.text: Contrast is a spotlight. Shine it on the star and dim it everywhere else.

quiz.question: Which type of contrast is the strongest at attracting the eye?
